Award.AwardTitle: Colloidal III-V Nanomaterials: New Opportunities in Chemistry and Device Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

III-V semiconductors, such as GaAs, InP, InAs and InSb, are used in laser diodes, photodetectors, fast electronic circuits and the most efficient solar cells. However, very limited attention has been paid to development of solution-processed forms of III-V semiconductors for low-cost manufacturing of this important class of materials and making it accessible to broad markets of energy-related technologies.
The research supported by the NSF Solid State and Materials Chemistry program focuses on new synthetic and surface chemistry for III-V nanomaterials. It will explore novel approaches to colloidal synthesis of III-V semiconductor nanocrystals. Special attention will be paid to development of new inorganic surface ligands for III-V nanostructures based on molecular metal chalcogenide complexes and pnictide Zintl ions. The combination of strong quantum confinement and new inorganic surface chemistry can lead to new physics due to the multi-valley band structure of III-V semiconductors and due to emergence of the collective electronic states (minibands) in strongly coupled nanocrystal assemblies; it may also lead to new applications for this important class of semiconductors.


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The fastest commercial transistors and the most efficient solar cells use III-V semiconductors such as GaAs. At the same time technological difficulties associated with preparation and handling III-V semiconductors do not allow them to compete with silicon and other less expensive materials for large consumer markets. This project supported by the NSF Solid State and Materials Chemistry program focuses on development of new soluble forms of III-V semiconductors for low-cost manufacturing of new materials for applications in green energy technologies. The proposed research will create a new class of inexpensive semiconductors suitable for applications in electronics, light-emitting devices and solar cells. Research program will also involve participation of underrepresented minority groups and public outreach to the south side Chicago community. These activities will help recruit minorities and disadvantaged students and promote their pursuit of careers in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
III-V semiconductors, such as GaAs, InP, InAs, are known for their excellent properties. These materials are used in lasers, electronics and solar cells. However, the technological and societal impact of III-V semiconductors is limited by their very high cost. This Project focused on development of solution-processed forms of III-V semiconductors for low-cost devices, such as printable light-emitting diodes, electronic circuits and thin-film solar cells.

Intellectual merit. Our work has demonstrated that colloidal III-V nanocrystals with inorganic molecular surface ligands offer a convenient route for low-cost manufacturing and device integration of III-V semiconductors, making these materials accessible to broad markets of energy-related technologies.

We have developed the colloidal synthesis of monodisperse GaAs quantum dots. We also demonstrated high electron mobility on solution-cast films of InAs nanocrystals and carried out systematic studies of III-V nanocrystal surface.

To achieve efficient charge transport in the materials made of nanocrystals, we introduced the concept of compositionally-matched semiconductor solders. We showed that compositionally-matched molecular “solders”, create new opportunities for printable electronics and optoelectronics, and open new design spaces for semiconductor technologies.

Development of human resources . This Project established a highly interdisciplinary research program. Training of four graduate students and three undergraduate students has been sponsored by this NSF Award. One undergraduate student supported by the award belongs to the Hispanic underrepresented minority group. 

Wenyong Liu has defended his PhD thesis “All Inorganic III-V Inks: Preparation, Surface Modification, Sintering and Electronic & Opto-electric Applications” in May 2014 and accepted postdoctoral position at Los Alamos National Laboratory. In 2016, he joined Research Staff at the Nanosys, Inc. located in San Jose, CA.

Dmitriy Dolzhnikov has defended his PhD thesis “Molecular solders for inorganic semiconductors” in April 2015 and moved on a postdoctoral position at Northwestern University.

All three undergraduate students successfully completed their education at the University of Chicago. One of them took a position at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and two other students joined graduate programs at Cornell University and Columbia University. Both have been awarded the NSF Graduate Research Fellowships.  

Broader impacts. Our outreach program promoted science education and awareness to inner-city student populations.  The research team working on this project has been actively involved in the educational outreach activities through the “Physics with a Bang” science fair at the University of Chicaco and the Science Club sessions at local public schools that have high enrollments of minorities and economically disadvantaged students. These activities effectively reach both adults and students in underrepresented minority neighborhoods on the South and Southwest sides of Chicago and promote their pursuit of careers in science and engineering.

We hold science clubs at Murray Language Academy and Drake Elementary. UChicago graduate students and postdocs contributed scientific expertise and mentored the weekly clubs that consisted of ~30 students. Our science club initiatives focused on hands-on science experiences that develop critical thinking, problem solving, and other fundamental investigative skills. Graduate student engagement in outreach activities teaches them to communicate complex research material to diverse audiences of various levels of education.
